title: At least one of my male characters really opens up emotionally, to his family. Is that realistic, when really tough and sad things has happened? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends entirely on how you have built this character up to that point. If you have created a reasonable personality for whom such a situation would be believable, or if you have created a situation where the shock of such a situation would be an important turning point in the character’s life then you could probably get away with it if it is well written. Surprise breaking of character can be effective if it’s important and rational within the story. Men, generally, tend to be stoic and withhold their emotions, but that is a generality and cannot be applied to every single male character, that would be boring. But if you have built such a stoic character then you had better have set up an exceptionally good reason for him to break out of that shell. A small example, My character of Brigadier General Chip York, USMC, a tough, stoic, combat proven Marine, opening up to his friend regarding the love of his life: “You envy me? You think I don’t have any doubts, that everything is simple and easy for us? You think I don’t worry about being 12 years older than her or that she’s a ravishing, gorgeous, world famous celebrity recognized everywhere we go and that every sane, healthy male on the planet fantasizes about having sex with her? “But I love her and if there’s one thing I HAVE learned about relationships it’s that you can’t spend your whole life waiting for the perfect one to come along. When you find one that feels pretty good you have to grab it and work with it and adapt to its problems as best you can. Otherwise you’re going to have a long, lonely, empty, life.” Out of character for Chip, something he would never admit or say to anyone but his friend Al, and then only in that specific situation. Not a perfect example, but you get the point.

Yes, it is realistic. Males are thought to be strong, never-shedding-tears creatures. That’s a myth. They too are humans. They too get vulnerable, and they too cry. So if something terrible had happened to your male character, like a break up, and if he is opening up emotionally, it is realistic. Check this out. I wrote one scene for you. He looked at his mother. She was there, staring at him. A shadow of grief crossed over her face as she realized something. “What happened, son?” He didn’t want to say anything. With trembling lips he was only able to say one word. “Nothing.” There was a pause. She came near to him and cupped her hands over his face. He tried his best to hide the pain behind the mask of his smile. “You know,” she said, “I’m there for you to listen.” Her simple words were the only thing he wanted to hear. And then he revealed his grief.

Yes. It can be realistic. It depends on the emotional intelligence of your character as well as the situation. For example, if he tends to bottle up his feelings, choosing to bear the weight on his own and a tragedy happens which can be minuscule or huge, pushes him over the edge, then in a fit, he opens up because the dam with his stoic mask, has broken and perhaps unintentionally he out pours emotions to his family. Another situation could be, he’s sensitive and yearns the compulsion of being adored or touch of sympathy that he’s been denied so long and his family is the closest thing he has left. The right mix of the situation, the character’s attitude and his family can make it realistic.

Indeed it is . I myself have had more than my share of sorrows in life . ( I have had joys too of course ) In my stories the most prominent feature about them is that they do experience both the joys and sorrows , trials and triumphs of life . It is more realistic to have someone in your story who is unafraid to walk in darkness every now and again as this helps one to more fully appreciate the Light !

response.answer_text: Depends on your character archetype. If this is someone who never relies on anyone and never opens up to anyone, it will either be unbelievable or it could be a great moment for you to explore some character growth, thus providing a great emotional payoff for your reader. Consider what type of character you have and whether the scenario I mentioned above might fit your character and your story.

response.answer_text: Yeah it is, I'm super emotional. I think about my emotions all the time and wonder what they are there and morph them to be what I want them to be. I love feeling. But every guy is different based on a personality type. I'm an INFP.
Sure, but you shouldn’t just accept that a scenario in a story is realistic. It’s your job as a writer to make sure it is.
All you have to do(!) is to write well enough to convince most of the readers who pick up your book.
It may be, what if one of your characters’ family is the reason why they had gone through tough times?
